baseline_groups.claim_summary: The cisterns treatment (reducing household vulnerability) decreases private requests to politicians, indicating that vulnerability sustains clientelism.
baseline_groups.notes: Corresponds to Table 3, Column 3 of the paper: OLS of ask_private_stacked on treatment and rainfall_std_stacked with municipality FE and year FE, clustered at neighborhood level. The 'baseline_rainfall' spec comes from the same regression but reports the rainfall_std_stacked coefficient, which is a separate estimand (the rainfall channel). The 'baseline_interaction' spec reports the interaction coefficient from Table 3 Col 4, which tests a distinct hypothesis (complementarity between treatment and rainfall).

baseline_groups.claim_summary: Rainfall shocks (increasing vulnerability) increase private requests to politicians.
baseline_groups.notes: This is the rainfall coefficient from the same Table 3 Col 3 regression. Rainfall is standardized so a positive rainfall shock reduces vulnerability and thus reduces private requests (negative coefficient expected). This is a distinct causal channel from the cisterns treatment.

global_notes: The paper has two main causal channels: (1) the experimental cisterns treatment and (2) rainfall shocks, both affecting vulnerability and consequently clientelistic behavior. Many specification rows use treatment variables that are interactions (treat_freq, treat_assoc, treat_high_rain, treat_2012, treat_2013, rain_2012, rain_2013, treat_rain_std) which test heterogeneity or related hypotheses rather than the core claim. The specification search also includes household-level vulnerability outcomes (Table 2) and individual-level outcomes (Table 1) that are mechanism checks, not the main clientelism claim. The duplicate spec 'robust/outcome/ask_private_stacked' is identical to the baseline and should be flagged. The spec 'robust/placebo/public_goods' duplicates 'robust/outcome/ask_public_stacked' (same regression, different labeling).
